name: Circle fans
description: The aim of the assignment was to create static generative art. In order to achieve this, I wanted to use randomness and repetition. I started by creating an ellipse and playing around with it. Then I created lines that were half the size of the ellipse. After that I used rotation and made 8 equal pieces using lines. I wanted to change the color of the balls every time the page was refreshed using the random function. I used a for loop and applied this shape through the page.
background: I came up with this idea while watching a tutorial from Matthew Epler about P5.js. In his tutorial, he created an ellipse and created lines and I tried to repeat the same steps. I wrote the wrong number by accident, but I really like the revised shape with more lines. Afterward, I wanted to repeated the shape. The last thing I wanted to do was change the color, so I used a random function to pick the colors.

name: Candy shop
description: My purpose was to create an interactive art project, and I started by looking for examples that might inspire me. As I went through the examples Garrit showed us during the lecture, I found an example called Grid. To understand how it works, I started playing around and changing rectangles to ellipses. In my version, I increased the number of shapes to 100, reduced the gap between shapes to 7 and reduced the size of the shapes to 10. By using the math random function, I was able to change the colors randomly to redish colors to make it interactive.
background: I came up with this idea while looking for examples Garrit provided during the lecture. Instead of rectangles, I used small ellipses to increase the number of shapes in the example. It happened spontaneously since I didn't plan to make something like that.

name: Circle to flower
description: As part of this project, I wanted to create an interactive art piece, but I also wanted to learn more about how angular motion works. Therefore, I began watching a video series by Daniel Shiffman called the Nature of Code. In his video, he created a rectangle and explained acceleration and velocity. I created a new shape using ellipses and made it look like a flower to understand it on my own. After that, I applied the same steps as in the video and played around with the numbers to make the shape move faster and increase its size. I used if blocks to decrease the size of the shape after one point since it was growing every time.
background: My initial idea was to draw a flower shape and rotate it, but I had some questions about how to do so. Upon watching a tutorial by Daniel Shiffman, I got inspired and decided to rotate the flowers using his instructions. Therefore, this artwork represents a combination of two ideas.

name: Shaky shaky
description: After watching Daniel Shiffman's tutorial, I became more interested in how angular motion works. This is why I played around with my old project called Circle to flower and tried to create different versions. In the end, I made the shapes smaller and used for loops to create more shapes.
background: I got inspired by Daniel Shiffman while adding movement to the shape. In order to make them more appealing, I wanted to place the shapes symmetrically to full screen.

name: Radiation in space
description: I used the Perlin noise function in order to create an interactive art project for the assignment. Watching Daniel Shiffman's tutorial helped me understand how Perlin Noise gives different values over time. I followed his tutorial at first, but then got creative and created my own version based on his example. The project was completely reworked after I switched from vertex to line, instead of using vertex. I then adjusted the stroke amount and position of the lines.
background: By making small changes to Daniel Shiffman's tutorial, I created this interactive art piece. As part of this project, I wanted to use the gestalt principle of proximity since when objects and elements are arranged together, they appear to have a relationship.

name: A cloudy day in Jonkoping
description: The goal of this project was to create an interactive art piece while learning how to use Perlin Noise. My first step was to look at the examples provided during the lecture in order to gain a better understanding of that. The first thing I did was play around with the numbers in the javascript file and see what effect they had on the project. By increasing the noise seed, I was able to create a project that looked like the sky. Because of that, I decided to use shades of blue in the design. As there were a variety of options at that time, I was not sure which function I should use to change the colours. Therefore, I asked chatgpt for some examples I could use. From there, I used the map function to create sky-like blue colours. In the final step, I multiplied the frame count by 0.05 to move the sky.
background: I got inspired from Garrits' example and Gorilla Sun's Perlin Noise tutorial to create a pattern that looks like sky using Perlin Noise. The blue color is often associated with the sky, so I chose shades of blue for this project.

name: Click and rotate
description: The purpose of the project was to create an interactive art piece. In order to accomplish this, I wanted to use particle systems. Using Garrits' example as a starting point, I changed the ellipses into rectangles. My next step was to change the colors of the rectangles by using a random function. I increased the frequency of the rectangles at the end.
background: My inspiration came from Garrits' particle example, then I applied color theory to it and adjusted it.

name: Talkative lines
description: The aim of the project was to add a sound. To understand how it works, I used one of Garrit's examples and added royalty-free music to that.
background: I got inspired by Garrits example then I added royalty free mp3 music to the project from from Pixabay.

name: Music is not liked by circles
description: I started by making changes to the project called talkative lines. I added feedback delay to the sound. Then changed the shape to an ellipse. Using the loop function, I created more ellipses. Finally, I changed the colours of it using the map function.
background: I got inspired by Garrits example then I added royalty free mp3 music to the project from Pixabay.

name: Marks behind circles
description: The purpose of this project was to revisit the previous projects from our last three labs. In order to accomplish this, I chose an interactive project that I had previously made. Since I had not played with its colour before, I decided to start changing it. I accidentally made some mistakes in the code and it ended up looking nice. My next step was to increase the acceleration and decrease the size of it. As a final step, I changed the stroke colour and applied the scale function to make this shape much larger.
background: This project is inspired by my old project called Circle to flower. I used color theory and the law of similarity from the Gestalt principles.

name: Bloody particles
description: The aim of the project was to revisit our previous project from the last three labs. To achieve this I chose an interactive project that I have already completed. Previously, particles were created when the mouse was clicked, but now I want particles to be created based on the mouse position. For this project, I wanted particles to create ellipses rather than rectangles. To achieve reddish colors for the particles, I used the map function and the particle's lifespan as a value.
background: In this project, I used colour theory and was inspired by my old project called click and rotate.
